Kenedy deal 'delayed', according to Chelsea sources

Newcastle United are expected to sign Kenedy on loan amid competition from an unnamed club but Antonio Conte has slowed the deal down due to concerns over his squad size, Goal understands.

Kenedy damaged his standing at Chelsea after being sent home from the club’s tour of Asia where he posted an offensive message on Instagram about China.

Kenedy is still expected to leave on loan but Conte is worried about his side’s lack of options as the club looks to add a few more names before the transfer window shuts.

Arsenal’s Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, Leicester City’s Danny Drinkwater and Everton’s Ross Barkley remain targets for the club as they seek more than one signing before transfer deadline day.

Dwight Gayle woke up to headlines in the national Sunday papers today claiming he could be sold by the Magpies.
He was left out of the side yesterday against West Ham as Rafa Benitez does not believe he is 100%.
The facts of the matter are that Newcastle would probably consider any big bids for Gayle though.
There are Championship clubs interested and as the minutes tick down for clubs in the window he would be an option.
On Gayle’s part, he’d like to stay but if Newcastle can make any incoming deal work in their favour they will look at a possible sale

上場美連奴精華


Rafa Benitez believes there are “similarities” between Newcastle United’s Mikel Merino and former World Cup-winning midfielder Xabi Alonso.

Merino was arguably the Magpies’ man of the match during Saturday’s 3-0 victory over West Ham United, in just his second start since arriving in English football, with the Spaniard putting in an assured all-round midfield display.

As a result, comparisons with former Liverpool, Real Madrid and Bayern Munich midfielder Alonso have arisen, and Benitez admits that he does see parallels in terms of their ability to read the game between the Spain great who he first brought to Anfield and the 21-year-old midfielder who arrived on Tyneside this summer.

“There are similarities,” Benitez replied when asked if Merino reminded him of Alonso, who the Newcastle boss managed between 2004 and 2009.

“I will tell you, though it maybe sounds stupid, that they are both Basque - from the Basque country.

“They are similar because of the position they are in and the way they read the game. Alonso’s long passing was better but Merino is more mobile and more dynamic.”

Merino joined Newcastle from Borussia Dortmund on an initial season-long loan this summer, but that deal includes a permanent-purchase clause.

And Benitez admits that he had been tracking the Spain Under-21 international for an extended period, and believes Merino will only get better over time in England.

“I’ve been tracking him for a while now. We knew him when he was in the Under-21s,” Benitez added.

“With him he hasn’t been playing regularly for a while so his job is to keep going, keep training, get as many minutes as he can under his belt and he will get better.

“Yes [he’s adapting to the pace], there have been a couple of situations [where he’s been caught out] but he is very dynamic. He is always moving.

“It’s a question of understanding the game here. He has natural composure on the ball.

“There were a lot of players I had at Liverpool in the beginning who came from Spain. It’s always difficult at first when you have quality they eventually adapt to the pace of the game”
